data.commitMessage:
[FABLG-6] Fix scripting error in Jenkinsfile

Replace raw bash with Jenkins DSL shell command
to collect the architecture of the slave node

Change-Id: Ia464903754ea74bb78c149488060feb3fec31550
Signed-off-by: Brett Logan <Brett.T.Logan@ibm.com>

comments.message:
I would think you want to validate that this worked. could be a switch (yea I know it's python so if:then:else) or possibly search for 'amd64' in ARCH. 'sed' will return OK status even if it did not find a match.
or
why not just ARCH = 'amd64' ?
or
ARCH = sh(uname -m)
if ARCH == x86_64
ARCH=amd64
else ERROR

Addressed...and added the if-statement. However, validating that uname returns a value is moot, it is a syscall to the kernels hard-coded information table. Validating that hard-coded kernel values exist is like validating that every Jenkins variable, like $WORKSPACE, is set, it's just something we have a fundamental expectation to be present.

This did cause me to realize I failed to trim the string though :)
If this were to fail, would the stack be enough to figure out what happened ? or do you need to catch this and add some info to make it easier.
ClonRefSpec already has its own error handling via try catch. So nothing necessary here
If this debug fine, but we don't really want this in the log once this gets merged.

I agree...there is quite a bit in this pipeline script that needs to be fixed...replaced...and just generally, I am going to submit another CR on top of this to clean up the pollution. I am not happy with a log of things in here.

Removed for this CR
error handling, what a novel idea!
Looking at this in gerrit the diff sez there is something changed here. I am unable to discern any difference... white space ?
I don't remember where, but somewhere there was trailing white space, Gerrit isn't showing it on the diff
The '{}' is only required to find the end of the variable name, and '/' is not a valid character. It is of course required to reference an array.
Not sure what you mean about '/' not being a valid character
This is cool, I have have been trying to get Ramesh to source a common file that is a 'library' of functions/aliases that can be use by all scripts.

If you want full path:
scripts_dir=$(readlink -f $(dirname $0))

Common practice is:
source $(dirname $0)/command.sh
You don't use anything from command.sh unless you plan to add to this script ?

Since this scripts is only being 'sourced' this line is treated as a comment and is a little misleading. If you want to put something the #!/bin/false is probably better since 'executing' this script is a useless.
No newline at end of revision file.
No newline at end of revision file.

data.commitMessage:
[FABLG-1] Implement common health check package

The healthz package provides a HealthHandler
object with which objects implementing the
HealthChecker interface can be registered.

The HealthHandler.ServerHTTP() implements
the http.Handler interface for use with
any http.Server.

Change-Id: Ia8b9bdd52343a1d27a42f98cb66879c5306c4519
Signed-off-by: Gari Singh <gari.r.singh@gmail.com>

comments.message: we can just delete even if the key doesn't exist, no?

I'm not sure this is the ideal model for a light weight service.

I would envision a health check thread working asynchronously and updating a map of component-->status, and the http requests just returning this map content (well, a point in time snapshot of it).

If some health checks are costly - there is not reason to do them synchronously from the an http dispatching goroutine.

I thought about doing it that way ... but I felt that the health checks themselves actually be lightweight and if there is some "heavy" check it could actually implement the background checks and just return it's current "state" when it's HealthCheck function is called.
Alternatively, we could add a ticker to each registration as you are suggesting.

I think we should keep this stuff super simple. If a health check implementation is heavy, it could/should maintain a last checked time stamp and return the cached result if the check completed within some short period of time.

The one concern I have is whether or not we want to allow concurrent execution of health checks or if we want to ensure handlers are externally serialized and never called concurrently from two go routines/requests.
this should ideally be an RWMutex, otherwise you'll probably going to have queued health checks.
Not sure why it returns one instead of being one.

In my little writeup, I suggested that the message would only be provided/needed when things didn't work. Do we want to document that behavior?

Alternatively, do we want to switch to a single error on return and use the error message as the failure reason?
You should provide the context that you received in the handler (or some derivative).
Do we care about the encoding of time? By default we get RFC3339.
I don't think we should provide any encoding options ... so the default (RFC3339) seemed as good as anything to me

One more - Since this is managed state, I'm not sure it should be exported. We have a lock and we expose methods to add and remove from the map so the only thing we don't have is a way of injecting at construction.

You know that I think we "hide" too much in general so I appreciate the export. If we didn't expose Register/Unregister, then I'd be fine with this. The implication would be that the Handlers need to be known up front. Since we're acting as a registry, it's a detail.
I'm assuming this exists for symmetry and that we don't know of a use case for it at runtime?
Correct.  Happy to remove if you prefer
It's fine - I was more curious if you had a use case in mind.
I was thinking a bit about things which might come and go like chaincode and channels (in the future of course)
We should be rejecting any method other than an HTTP GET.
Should pass along req.Context() to RunChecks. Ideally we decorate it with a timeout.
Sure .... but how do you imagine using this?

Well, to start, I think we should set a timeout on the context; something sane. The parent is also setup by the server implementation and will be canceled if the client goes away. If we do have long running checks, it also gives us a chance to cancel them.
Why not just have HealthHandler implement http.Handler by naming this ServeHTTP(resp http.ResponseWriter, req *http.Request)? Why return a HandlerFunc?
I chuckle as the handling should really be to say we're unhealthy instead of ignoring it. This shouldn't happen and if it does, it's not good.
I originally had that and happy to put it back but I could not for the life of my find any test case which would actually trigger the error.

You probably won't without injecting a marshaler dependency. Still think we should have the block that does the correct thing.

Alternatively, you could use a json.Encoder around the ResponseWriter and break the implementation of Write on the response writer to force an error.
doesn't usually matter in practice but this can fail as well.
Removed these tests and went with the private injection point as I added another private test function to to get the now internal map of healthCheckers
;) We just needed the status code to be bad when everything fails apart. In this case, I'd probably do a straight up 500 to indicate an error instead of trying to overload the 503.

data.subject: [FABLG-1] Implement common health check package

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.
Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Gari Singh

data.commitMessage:
[FABLG-1] Pass context to health checks

Pass a context on to the healthhecks.
The context has a configurable timeout
and it's parent (which is passed in via
the http.Request) was a cancel.

If the parent's cancel is triggered, simply
return as this means that the HTTP client
terminated its connection.

If the tiemout is triggered, return
HTTP status of request timeout

Change-Id: I52dc37d37b7ae7908fb7fdd98e41600d5a25bf2a
Signed-off-by: Gari Singh <gari.r.singh@gmail.com>
data.subject: [FABLG-1] Pass context to health checks

comments.message: Change has been successfully merged by Matthew Sykes

data.commitMessage:
HealthCheck() should simply return error

Changed the interface to return an error
rather than a message and boolean.

Makes the interface more consumable.

Change-Id: I3dd53aa4fe51e26423b3c07bbcf48f07aa005797
Signed-off-by: Gari Singh <gari.r.singh@gmail.com>
data.subject: HealthCheck() should simply return error

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

Tested this change in sandbox https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/sandbox/job/fabric-lib-go-verify-x86_64/5/console

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

There is an awful lot of boilerplate in this CR and I don't know that a lot of it makes sense.

I also believe that the structure of the groovy needs to be changed to stop looking at build names and rely more on parameters or environment variables.
Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.
Patch Set 5: Published edit on patch set 4.
Change has been successfully merged by Matthew Sykes

data.commitMessage:
FAB-13791 fabric-lib-go CI changes

This patch creates a Jenkinsfile to clone the refspec on the patchset
submission and clone the repository on the merge event. Jenkinsfile uses the
global shared library from the ci-management repository and execute unit-tests
and send the merge build failure notifications to jenkins-robot rocketChat
channel and submitter email address.

Jenkinsfile run on x platform for every verify and merge changes.
It executes unit-tests on clean environment after fetch the patchset
or clone the repository.

Change-Id: I263ba738e442ec1c1ed5ac19129604fc6121db03
Signed-off-by: rameshthoomu <rameshbabu.thoomu@gmail.com>

comments.message: where did this magic directory come from?

So, we need to change this every time the go version changes?
What about when the install paths fails?
Does every repo have their own instance of this?
This seems backwards. Parameters should be telling is what to do; the names of the builds should be irrelevant.
nit: whitespace (I see this copy-pasta in most of the Jenkinsfiles so it's clear that we're pretty much replicating boilerplate from copy/paste)

These sorts of references seem extremely fragile. Why are we doing it this way?

Coverage means that a parameter was specified that indicates clearly I want coverage - not that a specially named job triggered it. This is backwards.
The race detector should be enabled
What is the purpose of this script? There's nothing in this repo that uses images, npm, or node.

data.subject: FAB-13791 fabric-lib-go CI changes

comments.message: Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

In addition to the comment in the Makefile, all of the scripts have significant overlap. In particular, most have some exclusion rules.

Instead of duplicating that logic into all of the scripts (which is what was done in other repos), let's create file containing a collection of functions that can be sourced into the files. The scripts that are directly executable all need a shebang and have the execute bit turned on; the sourced file should have neither.

And, for discussion: because these scripts are part of a larger system and not really independent commands, I think we should .sh suffix on them. This makes it clear when we're referencing them that they are shell scripts and not python or perl or something else.

data.commitMessage:
FAB-13792 Build script to test fabric-lib-go changes

This change creates Makefile and supporting scripts to test and
validate change requests. The default make target is set to all
which executes checks and unit-tests.

Change-Id: Icbf9ca2434f88e493ff073f66b14c29c5910387b
Signed-off-by: rameshthoomu <rameshbabu.thoomu@gmail.com>

comments.message: I think you need to specify the duration type (m - minute, s - second, etc.). Otherwise you'll get an error.

This should likely be extracted to a script like everything else. Also, we don't want to limit parallelization with the -p flag.
The default timeout is 10m and that is *PLENTY* for unit tests. We shouldn't have that flag.

data.subject: FAB-13792 Build script to test fabric-lib-go changes

FAB-14201 Dockerize gotools and maintain versioning

This patch creates a Dockerfile which helps to maintain the versioning
and dockerize the gotools.

Change-Id: Ifa3be01aa7f9e6f49c7f7f24230786ac28c49b49
Signed-off-by: rameshthoomu <rameshbabu.thoomu@gmail.com>

comments.message:
If the repos have tags that include the version, let's use those.

For goimports, it should be release-branch.go1.11. For misspell it should be v0.3.4.
Let's be explicit about the GOPATH reference by using ${GOPATH}.
If this were the same as the previous, the layer would be cached.

data.subject: FAB-14201 Dockerize gotools and maintain versioning

data.commitMessage:
[FAB-16912] Fix check-license to ignore .

Signed-off-by: Ry Jones <ry@linux.com>
Change-Id: Ida60da6a88f4fdcb932a6f28203184edd5386356

comments.message:
Why would the '.' directory show up in `git diff` ?

I see the failure you hit

```
02:29:10  + make checks
02:29:10  Checking for license headers...
02:29:10  grep: .: Is a directory
02:29:10  The following files are missing SPDX-License-Identifier headers:
02:29:10  
02:29:10  .
02:29:10  
02:29:10  Please replace the Apache license header comment text with:
02:29:10  SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
02:29:10  Makefile:25: recipe for target 'license' failed
02:29:10  make: *** [license] Error 1
```

Something else is wrong and it's almost certainly not this.

data.subject: [FAB-16912] Fix check-license to ignore .
